title: The Yesterweb
note: A community dedicated to reclaiming the creative, non-commercial internet. A manifesto for the small web, complete with resources for building your own corner of the old net.

title: Hundred Rabbits
note: Two artists living on a sailboat, creating low-power, offline-first tools and games. Their entire digital practice runs on solar power. A beautiful example of sustainable, intentional computing.

title: Brutalist Websites
note: A curated collection of websites embracing raw, unpolished design. No smooth gradients or animations—just pure, structural honesty. The anti-portfolio.

title: Webcurios
note: Matt Muir's weekly dispatch of the web's weird underbelly. Every Friday, a lovingly-curated list of the strange, fascinating, and overlooked corners of the internet.

title: The Marginalian
note: Maria Popova's longstanding meditation on what it means to live a meaningful life. Essays on literature, philosophy, science, and art. The internet's most beautiful weekly newsletter.

title: Kicks Condor
note: A hand-coded wiki of hypertext essays, link collections, and meditations on the small web. Kicks Condor is part archivist, part poet—chronicling the indie web with genuine affection.

title: Low-Tech Magazine
note: A solar-powered, low-bandwidth magazine about forgotten technologies and sustainable living. When the sun sets, the website goes offline. Design as philosophy.

title: Every Noise at Once
note: A computationally generated scatter-plot of every music genre known to Spotify. Click a word, hear a sound. A mesmerizing, overwhelming map of human musical expression.

title: The Museum of Obsolete Media
note: A comprehensive archive of dead formats—from wax cylinders to Zip disks. Each entry documents the rise, fall, and technical specs of media we've left behind.

title: Radio Garden
note: Spin a globe and listen to live radio from anywhere on Earth. London in the morning, Tokyo at night. A reminder that the world is vast and full of voices.

title: The Pudding
note: Visual essays that make data feel human. Topics range from the linguistics of pop music to the representation of women in film. Journalism as interactive art.

title: Atlas Obscura
note: A guide to the world's hidden wonders—abandoned places, strange rituals, obscure museums. Travel writing for people who think the Eiffel Tower is boring.

title: Folksonomy
note: A taxonomy of internet subcultures, memes, and phenomena. An attempt to catalog the chaos. Each entry is written with academic seriousness and genuine curiosity.

title: Are.na
note: A platform for collaborative research and mood-boarding. Not social media—more like a shared library where ideas accumulate slowly, deliberately, and beautifully.

title: The HTML Review
note: A journal of literature as algorithmic systems. Each issue is a single webpage exploring poetics, code, and constraint-based writing. Pure digital literature.

title: Hacker News
note: The last great forum. Minimalist design, no downvotes on submissions, and a culture of thoughtful, civil discussion. A relic of Web 1.0 values in a Web 3.0 world.

title: Wiby
note: A search engine for the old web. Wiby only indexes lightweight, non-commercial, text-based sites. It's a time machine to 1997, when the web was weird and wonderful.

title: Geocities-izer
note: Turn any modern website into a garish GeoCities throwback—complete with tiled backgrounds, Comic Sans, and under-construction GIFs. A reminder of where we came from.

title: Cameron's World
note: A web-collage of text and images excavated from the buried neighbourhoods of GeoCities. A digital monument to the web's most maligned aesthetic era.

title: Internet Artifacts
note: A scrollable timeline of the internet's most iconic moments—from the first webcam to the first tweet. Each artifact is a portal to a different era of digital culture.
